question: Question_03_(b)
statement:
Let $R$ be the finite region in the $xy$-plane bounded by $x = 0$,
$y = 0$ and $y = \cos x$.\\ (b) Express the volume of the solid obtained
by rotating $R$ about the line $x = -2$ as an integral. \emph{Do not
evaluate the integral.}
sols:
A picture is included below. To solve this question, we need to use the
method of left and right side integration. Recall the formula

\begin{align*}V = \pi \int_{a}^{b}((x_{R}+s)^{2} - (x_{L}+s)^{2})\, dy\end{align*}

where we think of $x_{R}$ and $x_{L}$ as functions of \emph{y} and the
$s$ factor is the shifting factor (so basically this factor accounts for
what line we are rotating over - the picture should make this clear).
Here, the right most curve is $x_{R} = \arccos(y)$ and the left most
curve is $x_{L} = 0$ and the $s$ factor in this case is \emph{2}. The
last thing is the limits of integration. we know on the \emph{x}-axis,
from the previous problem, we were integrating from 0 to
$\tfrac{\pi}{2}$. Here however we are integrating from the \emph{y}-axis
so we want to know when $\cos(x)$ crosses the \emph{y}-axis. This occurs
when $y=1$. Thus, we have

\begin{align*}V = \pi\int_{0}^{1} ((\arccos(y)+2)^{2}-(2)^{2})\, dy = \pi\int_{0}^{1}((\arccos(y))^{2} + 4\arccos(y))\, dy\end{align*}

To challenge yourself, try showing the above is actually equal to
$\displaystyle \pi^2+2\pi$.

hints:
By solving the first part of this problem, you should know the points of
intersection. Drawing a picture will probably help.
We are rotating about an axis parallel to the \emph{y}-axis

Try modifying the formula

\begin{align*}\pi \int_{a}^{b}(x_{R}^{2} - x_{L}^{2}) \, dy\end{align*}

(Note: this entire problem can also be solved by interchanging the
\emph{x} and \emph{y} variables)
